title: Thousands of Welsh fans face Twickenham travel chaos this weekend |
text:
This was the scene at Twickenham Station on the opening match of the World Cup Credit: Stephen Paston/PA Wire Thousands of Welsh rugby fans travelling to Twickenham could face more travel issues this weekend after Wales' long-awaited World Cup clash with England.
There are fears some may even become stranded in London because of a lack of trains.
Saturday's match is due to finish at 9.30pm, leaving Wales supporters little chance of getting to Paddington Station in time to catch the last train home at 10pm.
Trains after 10pm only go as far as Bristol, and Great Western Railway have advised people to make alternative travel plans.
The news has prompted fresh criticism from fans of rail firms.
It's ridiculous. It's not like the tournament has happened suddenly - they've had five years to plan.
You don't have to be a sports anorak to know that England v Wales is a massive game - especially at the Rugby World Cup - fans from Wales would want to go.
The game should have either been played earlier or more trains and buses put on.
– Alun Edwards, Wales fan First Great Western apologised for 'severe overcrowding' Credit: Arriva Trains Wales Great Western Railway said they are running all the trains they can and are warning people that services will be 'extremely busy.'
Passengers travelling to Twickenham Stadium from further afield this Saturday are advised to check the time of their last train home to ensure onward connections are not missed, and are being warned that rail services from Twickenham will be very busy.
We are running all the trains we are able to subject to Network Rail work in the Severn Tunnel - and without impacting other customers travelling on Saturday evening or Sunday morning.
Passengers who have booked tickets have been advised of the last train service and have planned their travel arrangements accordingly.
– Spokesperson, Great Western Railway Earlier this week the company apologised to passengers for delays and 'severe overcrowding', as thousands of rugby fans tried to travel to Cardiff ahead of the Millennium Stadium's first 2015 World Cup game.
